description.narrative: The Horn of Africa is facing one of its most severe La Niña-induced droughts in recent history following three back-to-back poor rainy seasons, while South Sudan has suffered a fifth consecutive year of severe flooding. Almost 21 million people are in a food security “crisis” or worse (IPC phases 3 and above). The data from Ethiopia are only an estimation as an IPC analysis has not been carried out recently. More than 44 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, this number is higher than the people in food security crisis as it includes also people not categorised as extremely food insecure but still in need of some level of humanitarian assistance. In Somalia alone, more than half of the population needs assistance. In South Sudan, over 70% of the population is inneed of humanitarian aid. The crisis has a potential to worsen until and beyond June 2022. Even if the March-April-May rains will be average or above-average, there is an expectation that 7 to 11 million people will remain in afood security crisis or worse (IPC phases 3 and above) in Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia alone, through September 2022. There are already projections for an above-average rains in South Sudan which will potentially generate additional floods in South Sudan. The Horn of Africa Category 1 response aims to support 770,000 people through this crisis in the four countries. The response is multi-sectorial and includes components of WASH, EFVSL and Protection. The emphasis is on providing lifesaving intervention butat the same time investing in resilience.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam International was formed in 1995 by a group of independent non-governmental organizations. Their aim was to work together forgreater impact on the international stage to reduce poverty and injustice. The name "Oxfam" comes from the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief, founded in Britain in 1942. The group campaigned for food supplies to be sent through an allied naval blockade to starving women and children in enemy-occupied Greece during the Second World War. As well as becoming a world leader in the delivery of emergency relief, Oxfam International implements long-term development programs in vulnerable communities. We are also part of a global movement, campaigning with others, for instance, to end unfair trade rules, demand better health and education services for all, and to combat climate change. Today, there are 19 member organizations of the Oxfam International confederation. They are based in: Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hong Kong, Ireland, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Quebec, South Africa, Spain and the United States. The Oxfam International Secretariat is based in Oxford, UK. The Secretariat runs advocacy offices in Addis Ababa, Brussels, Geneva, New York and Washington DC.
